data.enText: a person who is captured and held prisoner by a person or group, and who may be injured or killed if people do not do what the person or group is asking

data.chText: 在银行抢劫案中有三名儿童被扣为人质。
data.enText: Three children were taken hostage during the bank robbery.

data.chText: 他被扣为人质几近一年。
data.enText: He was held hostage for almost a year.

data.chText: 政府正就释放人质进行谈判。
data.enText: The government is negotiating the release of the hostages.
a hostage to fortune

data.chText: 可能招惹麻烦（或担忧）的东西（或许诺）；造成后患的事物
data.enText: something that you have, or have promised to do, that could cause trouble or worry in the future

data.text: prisoner ♦ hostage ♦ captive ♦ detainee ♦ prisoner of war

data.chText: 以上各词和短语均指被捕获、关押的人。
data.enText: These are all words for a person who has been captured and is being kept somewhere.
prisoner

data.chText: 指被（敌人等）关起来的人、俘虏、战俘。
data.enText: a person who has been captured, for example by an enemy, and is being kept somewhere

data.chText: prisoner较常用的意思为囚犯、犯人。
data.enText: The more frequent meaning of prisoner is ‘a person who is kept in prison’.
hostage
a person who is captured and held prisoner by a person or group, and who may be injured or killed if people do not do what the person or group is asking
captive
( literary ) a person who is kept as a prisoner

data.chText: captive常用于涉及国王、王后、公主等人物的历史背景中，有时亦指政治组织关押持异见者。prisoner较常用以指战俘、俘虏。
data.enText: Captive often occurs in more historical contexts involving people such as kings, queens and princesses. It is also sometimes found in references to political organizations holding people against their will. Prisoner is more often used to talk about people who have been captured in war.
prisoner or captive?
detainee

data.chText: 尤指因政治原因，通常是未经审讯被扣留、关押的人
data.enText: a person who is kept in prison, especially for political reasons and often without a trial
prisoner of war
a person, usually a member of the armed forces, who is captured by the enemy during a war and kept in a prison camp until the war has finished
to hold/keep sb prisoner/hostage/captive
to free/release a prisoner/hostage/captive/detainee/a prisoner of war
to set free a prisoner/hostage/captive
to take sb prisoner/hostage/captive
to capture a prisoner/hostage
a political prisoner/hostage/detainee

simple_means.memory_skill: host 客人 + age 表行为 → 把客人〔留住〕→ 人质

data.enText: a hostage to fortune

data.chText: 可能招惹麻烦（或担忧）的东西（或许诺）；造成后患的事物
data.enText: something that you have, or have promised to do, that could cause trouble or worry in the future

tr: a prisoner who is held by one party to insure that another party will meet specified terms

value.def: A hostage is someone who has been captured by a person or organization and who may be killed or injured if people do not do what that person or organization demands.

example.ex: It is hopeful that two hostages will be freed in the next few days.
example.tran: 有两名人质可望在几天后获释。

value.def: If someone is taken hostage or is held hostage, they are captured and kept as a hostage.

example.ex: He was taken hostage while on his first foreign assignment as a television journalist.
example.tran: 他第一次作为电视记者出国采访时就被扣作人质。

value.def: If you say you are hostage to something, you mean that your freedom to take action is restricted by things that you cannot control.

example.ex: With the reduction in foreign investments, the government will be even more a hostage to the whims of the international oil price...
example.tran: 随着外资的减少，政府将更加受制于起伏不定的国际油价。

example.ex: Wine growers say they've been held hostage to the interests of the cereal and soybean farmers.
example.tran: 葡萄种植兼酿酒者说他们一直都为谷物和大豆种植者的利益所绑架。

value.tran: 受限制的人;不由自主的人

partsOfSpeech.dec: hospit 客人 + able …的 → 好客的
hospit 客人 + al 表名词 → 把病人当客人的地方 → 医院

partsOfSpeech.d: 主人（原意指招待客人的人）

partsOfSpeech.dec: host 客人 + age 表行为 → 把客人〔留住〕→ 人质
host 客人 + el 表地点 → 客人住的地方 → 旅馆
host 客人 + ess 表女性 → 女主人
